title.raw: 《孝武本紀》 Annals of the Xiaowu Emperor

sentences.zh: 孝武皇帝者，孝景中子也。

translations.text: Emperor Xiaowu was the middle son of Emperor Jing.

sentences.zh: 母曰王太后。

translations.text: His mother was Empress Wang.

sentences.zh: 孝景四年，以皇子為膠東王。

translations.text: In the fourth year of Emperor Jing's reign, as an imperial son he was enfeoffed as King of Jiaodong.

sentences.zh: 孝景七年，栗太子廢為臨江王，以膠東王為太子。

translations.text: In the seventh year of Emperor Jing's reign, the crown prince Li was deposed and became King of Linjiang, and the King of Jiaodong was established as crown prince.

sentences.zh: 孝景十六年崩，太子即位，為孝武皇帝。

translations.text: In the sixteenth year of Emperor Jing's reign he passed away, and the crown prince ascended the throne as Emperor Xiaowu.

sentences.zh: 孝武皇帝初即位，尤敬鬼神之祀。

translations.text: When Emperor Xiaowu first ascended the throne, he was especially reverent toward sacrifices to ghosts and spirits.

Emperor Xiaowu was the middle son of Emperor Jing. His mother was Empress Wang. In the fourth year of Emperor Jing's reign, as an imperial son he was enfeoffed as King of Jiaodong. In the seventh year of Emperor Jing's reign, the crown prince Li was deposed and became King of Linjiang, and the King of Jiaodong was established as crown prince. In the sixteenth year of Emperor Jing's reign he passed away, and the crown prince ascended the throne as Emperor Xiaowu. When Emperor Xiaowu first ascended the throne, he was especially reverent toward sacrifices to ghosts and spirits.

sentences.zh: 元年，漢興已六十餘歲矣，天下乂安，薦紳之屬皆望天子封禪改正度也。

translations.text: In the first year, the Han dynasty had already been established for over sixty years, and all under heaven was peaceful and secure. The scholars and officials all hoped the Son of Heaven would perform the feng and shan sacrifices and reform the calendar and regulations.

sentences.zh: 而上鄉儒術，招賢良，趙綰、王臧等以文學為公卿，欲議古立明堂城南，以朝諸侯。

translations.text: The emperor favored Confucian learning and summoned worthy scholars. Zhao Wan, Wang Zang and others became high ministers through their literary learning, wishing to discuss the ancient ways and establish a Mingtang south of the capital to receive the feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 草巡狩封禪改歷服色事未就。

translations.text: The plans for imperial tours, feng and shan sacrifices, calendar reform, and color regulations were not yet completed.

sentences.zh: 會竇太后治黃老言，不好儒術，使人微得趙綰等姦利事，召案綰、臧，綰、臧自殺，諸所興為者皆廢。

translations.text: At this time Empress Dowager Dou practiced Huang-Lao teachings and disliked Confucian learning. She sent people to secretly discover Zhao Wan and others' illicit dealings, summoned and interrogated Wan and Zang. Wan and Zang committed suicide, and all the institutions they had established were abolished.

sentences.zh: 後六年，竇太后崩。

translations.text: Six years later, Empress Dowager Dou passed away.

sentences.zh: 其明年，上徵文學之士公孫弘等。

translations.text: The next year, the emperor summoned literary scholars such as Gongsun Hong.

sentences.zh: 明年，上初至雍，郊見五畤。

translations.text: The next year, the emperor first went to Yong and performed suburban sacrifices to the five altars.

sentences.zh: 後常三歲一郊。

translations.text: Afterward he regularly performed suburban sacrifices every three years.

sentences.zh: 是時上求神君，捨之上林中蹄氏觀。

translations.text: At this time the emperor sought divine spirits and housed them in the Ti Shi pavilion in Shanglin Park.

sentences.zh: 神君者，長陵女子，以子死悲哀，故見神於先後宛若。

translations.text: The divine spirits were a woman from Changling who, grieving over her child's death, appeared as a spirit to her mother-in-law Wanruo.

sentences.zh: 宛若祠之其室，民多往祠。

translations.text: Wanruo sacrificed to her in her chamber, and many people went to sacrifice there.

sentences.zh: 平原君往祠，其後子孫以尊顯。

translations.text: Lord Pingyuan went to sacrifice there, and afterward his descendants became honored and eminent.

sentences.zh: 及武帝即位，則厚禮置祠之內中，聞其言，不見其人云。

translations.text: When Emperor Wu ascended the throne, he treated her with great courtesy and housed her shrine within the palace. People heard her words but did not see her person.

The next year, the emperor first went to Yong and performed suburban sacrifices to the five altars. Afterward he regularly performed suburban sacrifices every three years. At this time the emperor sought divine spirits and housed them in the Ti Shi pavilion in Shanglin Park. The divine spirits were a woman from Changling who, grieving over her child's death, appeared as a spirit to her mother-in-law Wanruo. Wanruo sacrificed to her in her chamber, and many people went to sacrifice there. Lord Pingyuan went to sacrifice there, and afterward his descendants became honored and eminent. When Emperor Wu ascended the throne, he treated her with great courtesy and housed her shrine within the palace. People heard her words but did not see her person.

sentences.zh: 是時而李少君亦以祠灶、穀道、卻老方見上，上尊之。

translations.text: At this time Li Shaojun also appeared before the emperor with methods of sacrificing to the stove god, grain immortals, and anti-aging techniques, and the emperor honored him.

sentences.zh: 少君者，故深澤侯入以主方。

translations.text: Shaojun was originally the son of a former Marquis of Shenze who served as master of techniques.

sentences.zh: 匿其年及所生長，常自謂七十，能使物，卻老。

translations.text: He concealed his age and place of birth, always claiming to be seventy, able to summon spirits and prevent aging.

sentences.zh: 其游以方遍諸侯。

translations.text: He traveled among the feudal lords with his techniques.

sentences.zh: 無妻子。

translations.text: He had no wife or children.

sentences.zh: 人聞其能使物及不死，更饋遺之，常餘金錢帛衣食。

translations.text: People heard he could summon spirits and achieve immortality, so they sent him gifts, always leaving abundant gold, money, silk, clothes, and food.

sentences.zh: 人皆以為不治產業而饒給，又不知其何所人，愈信，爭事之。

translations.text: Everyone thought he did not manage property yet was wealthy, and not knowing where he came from, they trusted him even more and competed to serve him.

sentences.zh: 少君資好方，善為巧發奇中。

translations.text: Shaojun was skilled in techniques and good at making clever predictions that hit the mark.

sentences.zh: 嘗從武安侯飲，坐中有年九十餘老人，少君乃言與其大父游射處，老人為兒時從其大父行，識其處，一坐盡驚。

translations.text: Once he drank with the Marquis of Wu'an, and seated there was an old man over ninety. Shaojun spoke of places where he had hunted with the old man's grandfather. The old man had followed his grandfather as a child and recognized the places. Everyone seated was astonished.

sentences.zh: 少君見上，上有故銅器，問少君。

translations.text: Shaojun saw the emperor, who had an ancient bronze vessel, and the emperor asked Shaojun about it.

sentences.zh: 少君曰：「此器齊桓公十年陳於柏寢。」

translations.text: Shaojun said: 'This vessel Duke Huan of Qi placed in the Bo chamber in his tenth year.'

sentences.zh: 已而案其刻，果齊桓公器。

translations.text: Then they checked the inscriptions, and indeed it was Duke Huan of Qi's vessel.

sentences.zh: 一宮盡駭，以少君為神，數百歲人也。

translations.text: The entire palace was astonished, considering Shaojun a divine being, a man of several hundred years.

At this time Li Shaojun also appeared before the emperor with methods of sacrificing to the stove god, grain immortals, and anti-aging techniques, and the emperor honored him. Shaojun was originally the son of a former Marquis of Shenze who served as master of techniques. He concealed his age and place of birth, always claiming to be seventy, able to summon spirits and prevent aging. He traveled among the feudal lords with his techniques. He had no wife or children. People heard he could summon spirits and achieve immortality, so they sent him gifts, always leaving abundant gold, money, silk, clothes, and food. Everyone thought he did not manage property yet was wealthy, and not knowing where he came from, they trusted him even more and competed to serve him. Shaojun was skilled in techniques and good at making clever predictions that hit the mark. Once he drank with the Marquis of Wu'an, and seated there was an old man over ninety. Shaojun spoke of places where he had hunted with the old man's grandfather. The old man had followed his grandfather as a child and recognized the places. Everyone seated was astonished. Shaojun saw the emperor, who had an ancient bronze vessel, and the emperor asked Shaojun about it. Shaojun said: 'This vessel Duke Huan of Qi placed in the Bo chamber in his tenth year.' Then they checked the inscriptions, and indeed it was Duke Huan of Qi's vessel. The entire palace was astonished, considering Shaojun a divine being, a man of several hundred years.

sentences.zh: 少君言於上曰：「祠灶則致物，致物而丹沙可化為黃金，黃金成以為飲食器則益壽，益壽而海中蓬萊僊者可見，見之以封禪則不死，黃帝是也。

translations.text: Shaojun said to the emperor: 'Sacrificing to the stove god summons spirits. Summoning spirits allows cinnabar and vermilion to be transformed into gold. Gold can be made into eating vessels which prolong life. Prolonging life allows the Penglai immortals in the sea to be seen. Seeing them and performing feng and shan sacrifices leads to immortality—the Yellow Emperor was like this.

sentences.zh: 臣嘗游海上，見安期生，食臣棗，大如瓜。

translations.text: I once traveled on the sea and saw An Qisheng, who fed me dates as large as melons.

sentences.zh: 安期生僊者，通蓬萊中，合則見人，不合則隱。」

translations.text: An Qisheng is an immortal who communicates with Penglai. When harmonious he appears to people, when not harmonious he hides.'

sentences.zh: 於是天子始親祠灶，而遣方士入海求蓬萊安期生之屬，而事化丹沙諸藥齊為黃金矣。

translations.text: Thereupon the emperor began personally sacrificing to the stove god, and sent fangshi to sea to seek An Qisheng and others from Penglai, and began the work of transforming cinnabar and various drugs into gold.

sentences.zh: 居久之，李少君病死。

translations.text: After some time, Li Shaojun fell ill and died.

sentences.zh: 天子以為化去不死也，而使黃錘史寬舒受其方。

translations.text: The emperor thought he had transformed and become immortal, and had Huang Hammer Official Kuan Shu receive his methods.

sentences.zh: 求蓬萊安期生莫能得，而海上燕齊怪迂之方士多相效，更言神事矣。

translations.text: Seeking Penglai and An Qisheng brought no results, but the fangshi of Yan and Qi along the sea who made strange and circuitous claims imitated each other, speaking even more of divine matters.

sentences.zh: 亳人薄誘忌奏祠泰一方，曰：「天神貴者泰一，泰一佐曰五帝。

translations.text: A man from Bo, Bo Youji, presented a memorial on sacrificing to Taiyi, saying: 'The most honored heavenly spirit is Taiyi, and Taiyi's assistants are the Five Emperors.

sentences.zh: 古者天子以春秋祭泰一東南郊，用太牢具，七日，為壇開八通之鬼道。」

translations.text: In ancient times the Son of Heaven sacrificed to Taiyi in the southeastern suburbs in spring and autumn, using the full sacrificial animals, for seven days, making an altar with eight pathways for the ghosts.'

sentences.zh: 於是天子令太祝立其祠長安東南郊，常奉祠如忌方。

translations.text: Thereupon the emperor ordered the Grand Invocator to establish the shrine in the southeastern suburbs of Chang'an, and regularly perform sacrifices according to Youji's methods.

sentences.zh: 其後人有上書，言「古者天子三年一用太牢具祠神三一：天一，地一，泰一」。

translations.text: Afterward someone presented a memorial saying: 'In ancient times the Son of Heaven used full sacrificial animals every three years to sacrifice to the Three Ones: Heaven One, Earth One, Taiyi.'

sentences.zh: 天子許之，令太祝領祠之忌泰一壇上，如其方。

translations.text: The emperor approved it and ordered the Grand Invocator to lead the sacrifices at Youji's Taiyi altar according to the methods.

sentences.zh: 後人復有上書，言「古者天子常以春秋解祠，祠黃帝用一梟破鏡；

translations.text: Later someone else presented a memorial saying: 'In ancient times the Son of Heaven regularly performed jie sacrifices in spring and autumn, sacrificing to the Yellow Emperor using one screech owl and a broken mirror;

sentences.zh: 冥羊用羊；

translations.text: Ming Yang used sheep;

sentences.zh: 祠馬行用一青牡馬；

translations.text: Si Ma used one blue stallion;

sentences.zh: 泰一、皋山山君、地長用牛；

translations.text: Taiyi, Gao Mountain Mountain Lord, Earth Elder used oxen;

sentences.zh: 武夷君用乾魚；

translations.text: Wuyi Jun used dried fish;

sentences.zh: 陰陽使者以一牛」。

translations.text: Yin Yang messengers used one ox.'

sentences.zh: 其後，天子苑有白鹿，以其皮為幣，以發瑞應，造白金焉。

translations.text: The next year, the emperor's gardens had a white deer, used its skin as currency to respond to auspicious omens, made white gold.

sentences.zh: 其明年，郊雍，獲一角獸，若麃然。

translations.text: The next year, performing suburban sacrifices at Yong, obtained a one-horned beast, like a muntjac.

sentences.zh: 有司曰：「陛下肅祗郊祀，上帝報享，錫一角獸，蓋麟云。」

translations.text: The officials said: 'Your Majesty has solemnly performed suburban sacrifices, and the August Emperor has bestowed reward, giving a one-horned beast, probably a unicorn.'

sentences.zh: 於是以薦五畤，畤加一牛以燎。

translations.text: Thereupon offered it to the five altars, each altar adding one ox for burnt offering.

translations.text: Then the King of Jibei thought the emperor was about to perform feng and shan, so he presented a memorial offering Mount Tai and its neighboring towns.

sentences.zh: 天子受之，更以他縣償之。

translations.text: The emperor accepted it, and compensated with other counties.

sentences.zh: 常山王有罪，遷，天子封其弟於真定，以續先王祀，而以常山為郡。

translations.text: The King of Changshan committed a crime and was demoted. The emperor enfeoffed his younger brother in Zhending to continue the ancestral sacrifices, and made Changshan a commandery.

sentences.zh: 然後五嶽皆在天子之郡。

translations.text: Then all five sacred mountains were within the emperor's commandery.

sentences.zh: 其明年，齊人少翁以鬼神方見上。

translations.text: The next year, the Qi man Shao Weng appeared before the emperor with ghost and spirit techniques.

sentences.zh: 上有所幸王夫人，夫人卒，少翁以方術蓋夜致王夫人及灶鬼之貌云，天子自帷中望見焉。

translations.text: The emperor had favored Lady Wang, who passed away. Shao Weng used techniques to make Lady Wang and the stove god appear at night, and the emperor saw them from behind the curtains.

sentences.zh: 於是乃拜少翁為文成將軍，賞賜甚多，以客禮禮之。

translations.text: Thereupon he appointed Shao Weng as Literary General, with many rewards, treating him with guest rites.

sentences.zh: 文成言曰：「上即欲與神通，宮室被服不象神，神物不至。」

translations.text: The Literary General said: 'If Your Majesty wishes to communicate with the spirits, the palace chambers and clothing should resemble the spirits, then spirit objects will arrive.'

sentences.zh: 乃作畫雲氣車，及各以勝日駕車辟惡鬼。

translations.text: Then made cloud chariots and feathered carriages, and each chose auspicious days to drive carriages to avoid evil ghosts.

sentences.zh: 又作甘泉宮，中為臺室，畫天、地、泰一諸神，而置祭具以致天神。

translations.text: Also built Ganquan Palace, making it a platform chamber in the center, painting the heavens, earth, and Taiyi and various spirits, placing sacrificial utensils to summon heavenly spirits.

sentences.zh: 居歲餘，其方益衰，神不至。

translations.text: After more than a year, his techniques increasingly declined, spirits did not arrive.

sentences.zh: 乃為帛書以飯牛，詳弗知也，言此牛腹中有奇。

translations.text: Then wrote on silk and fed it to an ox, pretending not to know, saying this ox's belly contained something strange.

sentences.zh: 殺而視之，得書，書言其怪，天子疑之。

translations.text: Killed and examined it, obtained the writing, which spoke of marvels. The emperor was suspicious.

sentences.zh: 有識其手書，問之人，果（為）［偽］書。

translations.text: Someone recognized the handwriting, questioned the person, and indeed it was forged writing.

sentences.zh: 於是誅文成將軍而隱之。

translations.text: Thereupon executed the Literary General while concealing it.

After more than a year, his techniques increasingly declined, spirits did not arrive. The emperor was suspicious. Someone recognized the handwriting, questioned the person, and indeed it was forged writing. Thereupon executed the Literary General while concealing it.

sentences.zh: 其後則又作柏梁、銅柱、承露僊人掌之屬矣。

translations.text: Afterward then built the Cypress Beam Hall, copper pillars, dew-catching immortals and such.
Afterward then built the Cypress Beam Hall, copper pillars, dew-catching immortals and such.

sentences.zh: 文成死明年，天子病鼎湖甚，巫醫無所不致，（至）不愈。

translations.text: The year after the Literary General died, the emperor fell gravely ill at Dinghu, and no witch doctors were not summoned, but he did not recover.

sentences.zh: 游水發根乃言曰：「上郡有巫，病而鬼下之。」

translations.text: You Shui Fa Gen said: 'In Shang Commandery there is a witch who, when ill, ghosts descend to her.'

sentences.zh: 上召置祠之甘泉。

translations.text: The emperor summoned and housed her shrine in Ganquan.

sentences.zh: 及病，使人問神君。

translations.text: When he fell ill, sent people to ask the divine spirits.

sentences.zh: 神君言曰：「天子毋憂病。

translations.text: The divine spirits said: 'The emperor should not worry about illness.

sentences.zh: 病少愈，彊與我會甘泉。」

translations.text: When the illness improves slightly, force yourself to meet me in Ganquan.'

sentences.zh: 於是病愈，遂幸甘泉，病良已。

translations.text: Thereupon the illness improved, and he went to Ganquan, and the illness was completely cured.

sentences.zh: 大赦天下，置壽宮神君。

translations.text: Granted great amnesty to all under heaven, established the Longevity Palace for the divine spirits.

sentences.zh: 神君最貴者（大夫）［太一］，其佐曰大禁、司命之屬，皆從之。

translations.text: The most honored divine spirit was Taiyi, its assistants called Great Prohibition, Siming and such, all following it.

sentences.zh: 非可得見，聞其音，與人言等。

translations.text: Could not be seen, but heard its voice, speaking like a person.

sentences.zh: 時去時來，來則風肅然也。

translations.text: Sometimes left, sometimes came; when coming, the wind was solemn.

sentences.zh: 居室帷中。

translations.text: Resided in chambers and tents.

sentences.zh: 時晝言，然常以夜。

translations.text: Sometimes spoke in daytime, but usually at night.

sentences.zh: 天子祓，然後入。

translations.text: The emperor performed purification, then entered.

sentences.zh: 因巫為主人，關飲食。

translations.text: The witch acted as host, managing food and drink.

sentences.zh: 所欲者言行下。
